@realmoney Jan 27, 2021 | 10:40 AM EST DOUG KASS The Fundamental Difference Between Being Short GameStop and Tesla * Many are becoming hyperbolic and are ignoring the facts I am seeing some comparisons made between (GME) and (TSLA) on the chat sites, on Twitter and e

lsewhere. Some suggest that if GME can go to $380 why can't TSLA go to $2000? Of course anything is possible - but I prefer dealing with facts and stats, especially as it relates to short interest which seems to be the primary reason why GME has rocketed into the

stratosphere. The short position in GME is about 70 million shares, or 140% of the share float of 47 million shares. By contrast, the short position in TSLA is only about 60 million shares compared to the float of 760 million shares, or only 8% of TSLA's float.
That is a big, big difference. @jimcramer @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC @threadreaderapp unroll

@business In all of my appearances on Market Surveillance over the last few years I have said that most individuals should never short. Those that do short should consider obeying my two core shorting tenets - something I have always emphasized with @tomkeene:

* Never short stocks whose short interest exceeds about 5-6% of the float. * Never short stocks whose short interest exceeds five days average trading volume (over the last four weeks). I can't begin to tell you how much money I have saved by committing to these short selling

tenets. I have been a short seller for four decades. Learn from this, memorize this. I have the short selling scars on back to prove it when I was a "yute." @jimcramer @andrewrsorkin @SquawkCNBC @beckyquick @lizclaman @riakerversal @ScottWapnerCNBC unroll

@realmoney $GME (2021) Out Resorts, Resorts International(1979) ... * I think $GME and its like are a threat to our system. * How to cure the deficit? A transaction tax would raise revenue and cure the problem in 30 seconds. A $.05 tax on just $GME yesterday would have

raised over $100mm. *It will take years to uncover the criminality. I think $GME is worth zero after following it since it’s birth. *Hard to see how this ends well. Its only a matter of hours before the regulators act (my guess). @jimcramer @tomkeene @andrewrsorkin

There are a number of reasons why shorts are difficult: * Stocks gravitate higher over time. * Reward v risk is asymmetric - one can lose an infinite amount on the short side but only make 100% if a stock goes to zero. * Most importantly, a short that goes against you

becomes a larger percentage of your portfolio. A long that goes against you becomes a smaller percentage of your portfolio. @realmoney @tomkeene @jimcramer @SquawkCNBC @carlquintanilla @ScottWapnerCNBC @riskreversal unroll
very correct

Speculative, heavily shorted gewgaws zoomed higher -- perhaps taking the oxygen from traditional high octane/growth equities. Meanwhile, some of my fundamental shorts like ($PTON) (-$9.35) and ($CVNA) (-$11.44) cratered today. I have been adding consistently to

these over the last few weeks Disney (DIS) fell by -$2.33. M inexplicably rose by nearly +$2. Homebuilders were mixed. One of my core and basic shorting tenets is never to short a stock in which short interest exceeds five to six days of average trading volume

(over the last month) and to avoid shorts in which company short interest exceeds 5% to 6% of the company's float. The short squeezes in ($GME) and the other shiny objects of speculation over the last month are testimony to this strategy of risk control and provides validity
